critique: This document is an executive order that exempts certain positions from a salary schedule prescribed in a previous executive order. These positions are consultants, experts, specialists, attorneys, and other similar positions that are intermittently employed on a per diem basis or employed on an annual basis at amounts representing the value of part-time service required. The incumbents of these positions are or have been paid from the public works or other emergency funds administered by the Secretary of the Interior or by the Federal Works Administrator through the Commissioner of Public Works, available during the fiscal year 1942. The order does not seem to have a strong ideological tilt, nor does it directly address immigration, executive power, federalism, national security, economic regulation, or social inclusion. However, by exempting certain positions from a salary schedule, it could be argued that the order promotes deregulation to a small extent. It is difficult to assess the impact on executive power without more context, but it does not appear to significantly expand or restrict it. The order seems to be primarily focused on administrative efficiency and flexibility in hiring for public works projects during a specific fiscal year.
